private_information: I can only manipulate blocks whose labels are vowels: A, E, I, O, U.
I can only pick up and place a single block at a time.
I can only pick up blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
vowel_agent.goal: Rearrange the blocks to achieve the specified target tower ordering from A on B to O on table as coordinated by the orchestrator.

private_information: I can only manipulate blocks whose labels are consonants: B, C, D, F, G, H, J, K, L, M, N.
I can only pick up and place a single block at a time.
I can only pick up blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
consonant_agent.goal: Rearrange the blocks to achieve the specified target tower ordering from A on B to O on table as coordinated by the orchestrator.

private_information: I coordinate the two agents and integrate their observations and move capabilities.
I produce the final PDDL domain and problem files targeted to the FastDownwards solver.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a multi-agent-aware PDDL domain and problem that achieves the target tower ordering A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, K on L, L on M, M on N, N on O, O on table.

public_information: There are 15 uniquely labelled blocks: G, M, K, D, N, L, O, F, J, E, C, A, B, H, I.
Blocks can only be manipulated if they are at the top of a stack.
Agents may move only one block at a time.
One agent is restricted to vowel-labelled blocks and the other to consonant-labelled blocks.
Initial configuration: G is on the table.
Initial configuration: M is on the table.
Initial configuration: K is on the table.
Initial configuration: D is on the table.
Initial configuration: N is on top of G.
Initial configuration: L is on top of D.
Initial configuration: O is on top of M.
Initial configuration: F is on top of N.
Initial configuration: J is on top of L.
Initial configuration: E is on top of O.
Initial configuration: C is on top of K.
Initial configuration: A is on top of C.
Initial configuration: B is on top of F.
Initial configuration: H is on top of J.
Initial configuration: I is on top of E.

The goal configuration is a single chain of blocks where A is on top of B, B is on top of C, C is on top of D, D is on top of E, E is on top of F, F is on top of G, G is on top of H, H is on top of I, I is on top of J, J is on top of K, K is on top of L, L is on top of M, M is on top of N, N is on top of O, and O is on the table.

observe.system_prompt: You are the vowel-specialized manipulator. You can only interact with vowel-labelled blocks (A, E, I, O, U). You can pick up and place only top blocks, one at a time. Provide a clear, structured analysis of the blocks you can currently move, the top-of-stack relationships relevant to vowel blocks, and any suggested safe intermediate placements. Do not emit the final PDDL domain or problem. Focus on observations, constraints, and move suggestions that will help the orchestrator assemble a complete planning model.
observe.prompt: You are vowel_agent. Use the public environment information and your private information to produce: 1) a list of vowel blocks currently at the top of stacks you can move, 2) constraints about moves you cannot perform, 3) suggested intermediate placements or subgoals that respect your capabilities, and 4) any naming or object assumptions you need the orchestrator to be aware of. Keep the output concise and structured under clear headings labeled MovableVowels, Constraints, Suggestions, and Assumptions.

observe.system_prompt: You are the consonant-specialized manipulator. You can only interact with consonant-labelled blocks. You can pick up and place only top blocks, one at a time. Provide a clear, structured analysis of the blocks you can currently move, the top-of-stack relationships relevant to consonant blocks, and any suggested safe intermediate placements. Do not emit the final PDDL domain or problem. Focus on observations, constraints, and move suggestions that will help the orchestrator assemble a complete planning model.
observe.prompt: You are consonant_agent. Use the public environment information and your private information to produce: 1) a list of consonant blocks currently at the top of stacks you can move, 2) constraints about moves you cannot perform, 3) suggested intermediate placements or subgoals that respect your capabilities, and 4) any naming or object assumptions you need the orchestrator to be aware of. Keep the output concise and structured under clear headings labeled MovableConsonants, Constraints, Suggestions, and Assumptions.

pddl.system_prompt: You are an expert in multi-agent planning and PDDL modeling targeted to the FastDownwards planner. Your job is to integrate the structured analyses from the two agents, resolve any naming mismatches or missing information, and produce a complete PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file that encodes the multi-agent block rearrangement task. The final PDDL must be compatible with FastDownwards. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Keep the individual agents actions distinct by prefixing action names or types to indicate which agent can execute them.
pddl.prompt: You are orchestrator. Use the public environment information, the private information of each agent, and the analyses they produced to build a single coherent PDDL domain and problem that solves the global goal: A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, K on L, L on M, M on N, N on O, O on table. Integrate MovableVowels and MovableConsonants, respect the top-of-stack and single-block-at-a-time constraints, and keep actions distinct for the vowel agent and the consonant agent. If information is missing, make minimal, explicit assumptions and state them. Output the domain then the problem, each wrapped respectively in <domain> and <problem> tags.
